articles.headline: Milwaukee Officer Is Acquitted in Killing of Sylville Smith
articles.snippet: The death last August touched off two days of protests and violence on Milwaukee’s north side. The jury decided the shooting had been justified.
articles.abstract: The death last August touched off two days of protests and violence on Milwaukee’s north side. The jury decided the shooting had been justified.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The latest high-profile prosecution of a police officer for a fatal shooting ended in an acquittal on Wednesday, as jurors cleared a Milwaukee officer of wrongdoing in the death of a 23-year-old man, Sylville K. Smith.
articles.byline: By Kay Nolan and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Uber’s Lesson: Silicon Valley’s Start-Up Machine Needs Fixing
articles.snippet: Travis Kalanick, who stepped down as Uber’s C.E.O., had many enablers who turned a blind eye to the company’s faults because it was growing quickly.
articles.abstract: Travis Kalanick, who stepped down as Uber’s C.E.O., had many enablers who turned a blind eye to the company’s faults because it was growing quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick’s spectacular rise and fall at Uber contains many lessons for the technology industry. But one lesson should rise above the others: This was not just Mr. Kalanick’s failure — it was far bigger.

articles.headline: A Kansas Investment Firm Spurring Change on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Creative Planning is at the vanguard of a profound shift in finance — from firms peddling products for a fee toward independent, low-cost advice.
articles.abstract: Creative Planning is at the vanguard of a profound shift in finance — from firms peddling products for a fee toward independent, low-cost advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEAWOOD, Kan. — Tucked away in a sleepy office park in this Kansas City suburb, a $26 billion investment advisory firm is helping drive Wall Street’s latest wealth boom.

articles.headline: When Helicopter Parents Hover Even at Work
articles.snippet: The father of the basketball star Lonzo Ball has taken an assertive role in his son’s career, reflecting a larger trend as millennials come of age.
articles.abstract: The father of the basketball star Lonzo Ball has taken an assertive role in his son’s career, reflecting a larger trend as millennials come of age.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the cameras start rolling Thursday night at Barclays Center, scene of the National Basketball Association draft, one of the biggest stories won’t be a player, but a parent: LaVar Ball, father of the U.C.L.A. phenom Lonzo Ball, who is projected to be among the top five picks.

articles.headline: Abortion Adds Obstacle as Republicans Plan to Unveil Health Bill
articles.snippet: The Republican leadership in the Senate plans to unveil a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but senators remain divided over issues from abortion to Medicaid.
articles.abstract: The Republican leadership in the Senate plans to unveil a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but senators remain divided over issues from abortion to Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Abortion flared up Wednesday as the latest hot-button issue to complicate passage of a bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, which Senate Republican leaders hope to unveil on Thursday and pass next week.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Inside Travis Kalanick’s Resignation as Uber’s C.E.O.
articles.snippet: At a Chicago hotel on Tuesday, two venture capitalists presented Mr. Kalanick with a list of demands, including his resignation by the end of the day.
articles.abstract: At a Chicago hotel on Tuesday, two venture capitalists presented Mr. Kalanick with a list of demands, including his resignation by the end of the day.
articles.lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick’s final hours as Uber’s chief executive played out in a private room in a downtown Chicago hotel on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Investors Flexed Their Muscles in Uber Fight
articles.snippet: Start-up financiers have deferred boardroom control to founders in recent years. Travis Kalanick’s ouster indicates that could be changing.
articles.abstract: Start-up financiers have deferred boardroom control to founders in recent years. Travis Kalanick’s ouster indicates that could be changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The conventional wisdom in the world of Silicon Valley start-ups has been that the founders call the shots and that the investors are cheerleaders — and sometimes enablers — of the entrepreneurs they backed.

articles.headline: Tough Task for Next Uber Leader: Mending Fences With Drivers
articles.snippet: With Travis Kalanick out as Uber’s chief executive, the company has a chance to improve its treatment of drivers. An option for tipping drivers is a start.
articles.abstract: With Travis Kalanick out as Uber’s chief executive, the company has a chance to improve its treatment of drivers. An option for tipping drivers is a start.
articles.lead_paragraph: The huge, headline-grabbing news out of Uber this week was the resignation of its chief executive, Travis Kalanick, under pressure from the company’s board, a stunning move that capped a monthslong crisis involving sexual harassment, executive misbehavior and Uber’s hard-nosed culture.

articles.headline: In Qatar Airways, American Airlines May Have an Unwanted Suitor
articles.snippet: The unsolicited approach comes amid criticism from United States carriers that Persian Gulf competitors have an unfair advantage.
articles.abstract: The unsolicited approach comes amid criticism from United States carriers that Persian Gulf competitors have an unfair advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Akbar al-Baker, the chief executive of Qatar Airways, recently approached his counterpart at American Airlines, a bitter rival, with some news: His state-owned company wanted to buy a 10 percent stake in American.
articles.byline: By Micah Maidenberg, Alan Rappeport and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Senate Health Care Bill Includes Deep Cuts to Medicaid
articles.snippet: Senate Republican leaders released their bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, even as enough senators to block it declared their opposition.
articles.abstract: Senate Republican leaders released their bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, even as enough senators to block it declared their opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans, who for seven years have promised a repeal of the Affordable Care Act, took a major step on Thursday toward that goal, unveiling a bill to make deep cuts in Medicaid and end the law’s mandate that most Americans have health insurance.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: An Index-Fund Evangelist Is Straying From His Gospel
articles.snippet: Burton Malkiel, author of “A Random Walk Down Wall Street,” says looking for market inefficiencies can beat passive investing, which he long endorsed.
articles.abstract: Burton Malkiel, author of “A Random Walk Down Wall Street,” says looking for market inefficiencies can beat passive investing, which he long endorsed.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his classic 1973 book “A Random Walk Down Wall Street,” Burton Malkiel, a Princeton economics professor, made an assertion that was startling at the time: that “a blindfolded monkey throwing darts at the stock listings could select a portfolio that would do just as well as one selected by the experts.”
